Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Good evening from the Thomas and Mack Center at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: I'm Chris Wallace of Fox News, and I welcome you to the third and final of the 2016 presidential debates between Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: This debate is sponsored by the Commission on Presidential Debates.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: The commission has designed the format: Six roughly 15-minute segments with two-minute answers to the first question, then open discussion for the rest of each segment.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Both campaigns have agreed to those rules.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: For the record, I decided the topics and the questions in each topic.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: None of those questions has been shared with the commission or the two candidates.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: The audience here in the hall has promised to remain silent.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: No cheers, boos, or other interruptions so we and you can focus on what the candidates have to say.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: No noise, except right now, as we welcome the Democratic nominee for president, Secretary Clinton, and the Republican nominee for president, Mr. Trump.

Speaker: SYSTEM
Text: (APPLAUSE)

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Secretary Clinton, Mr. Trump, welcome.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Let's get right to it.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: The first topic is the Supreme Court.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: You both talked briefly about the court in the last debate, but I want to drill down on this, because the next president will almost certainly have at least one appointment and likely or possibly two or three appointments.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Which means that you will, in effect, determine the balance of the court for what could be the next quarter century.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: First of all, where do you want to see the court take the country?

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: And secondly, what's your view on how the Constitution should be interpreted?

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Do the founders' words mean what they say or is it a living document to be applied flexibly according to changing circumstances?

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: In this segment, Secretary Clinton, you go first.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: You have two minutes.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Thank you very much, Chris.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And thanks to UNLV for hosting us.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: You know, I think when we talk about the Supreme Court, it really raises the central issue in this election, namely, what kind of country are we going to be?

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: What kind of opportunities will we provide for our citizens?

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: What kind of rights will Americans have?

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And I feel strongly that the Supreme Court needs to stand on the side of the American people, not on the side of the powerful corporations and the wealthy.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: For me, that means that we need a Supreme Court that will stand up on behalf of women's rights, on behalf of the rights of the LGBT community, that will stand up and say no to Citizens United, a decision that has undermined the election system in our country because of the way it permits dark, unaccountable money to come into our electoral system.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I have major disagreements with my opponent about these issues and others that will be before the Supreme Court.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: But I feel that at this point in our country's history, it is important that we not reverse marriage equality, that we not reverse Roe v. Wade, that we stand up against Citizens United, we stand up for the rights of people in the workplace, that we stand up and basically say: The Supreme Court should represent all of us.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: That's how I see the court, and the kind of people that I would be looking to nominate to the court would be in the great tradition of standing up to the powerful, standing up on behalf of our rights as Americans.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And I look forward to having that opportunity.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I would hope that the Senate would do its job and confirm the nominee that President Obama has sent to them.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: That's the way the Constitution fundamentally should operate.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: The president nominates, and then the Senate advises and consents, or not, but they go forward with the process.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Secretary Clinton, thank you.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Mr. Trump, same question.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Where do you want to see the court take the country?

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: And how do you believe the Constitution should be interpreted?

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Well, first of all, it's great to be with you, and thank you, everybody.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: The Supreme Court: It's what it's all about.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Our country is so, so -- it's just so imperative that we have the right justices.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Something happened recently where Justice Ginsburg made some very, very inappropriate statements toward me and toward a tremendous number of people, many, many millions of people that I represent.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: And she was forced to apologize.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: And apologize she did.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: But these were statements that should never, ever have been made.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We need a Supreme Court that in my opinion is going to uphold the Second Amendment, and all amendments, but the Second Amendment, which is under absolute siege.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I believe if my opponent should win this race, which I truly don't think will happen, we will have a Second Amendment which will be a very, very small replica of what it is right now.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: But I feel that it's absolutely important that we uphold, because of the fact that it is under such trauma.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I feel that the justices that I am going to appoint -- and I've named 20 of them -- the justices that I'm going to appoint will be pro-life.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: They will have a conservative bent.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: They will be protecting the Second Amendment.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: They are great scholars in all cases, and they're people of tremendous respect.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: They will interpret the Constitution the way the founders wanted it interpreted.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: And I believe that's very, very important.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I don't think we should have justices appointed that decide what they want to hear.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: It's all about the Constitution of -- of -- and so important, the Constitution the way it was meant to be.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: And those are the people that I will appoint.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Mr. Trump, thank you.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: We now have about 10 minutes for an open discussion.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: I want to focus on two issues that, in fact, by the justices that you name could end up changing the existing law of the land.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: First is one that you mentioned, Mr. Trump, and that is guns.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Secretary Clinton, you said last year, let me quote, "The Supreme Court is wrong on the Second Amendment."

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: And now, in fact, in the 2008 Heller case, the court ruled that there is a constitutional right to bear arms, but a right that is reasonably limited.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Those were the words of the Judge Antonin Scalia who wrote the decision.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: What's wrong with that?

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Well, first of all, I support the Second Amendment.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I lived in Arkansas for 18 wonderful years.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I represented upstate New York.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I understand and respect the tradition of gun ownership.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: It goes back to the founding of our country.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: But I also believe that there can be and must be reasonable regulation.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Because I support the Second Amendment doesn't mean that I want people who shouldn't have guns to be able to threaten you, kill you or members of your family.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And so when I think about what we need to do, we have 33,000 people a year who die from guns.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I think we need comprehensive background checks, need to close the online loophole, close the gun show loophole.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: There's other matters that I think are sensible that are the kind of reforms that would make a difference that are not in any way conflicting with the Second Amendment.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: You mentioned the Heller decision.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And what I was saying that you referenced, Chris, was that I disagreed with the way the court applied the Second Amendment in that case, because what the District of Columbia was trying to do was to protect toddlers from guns and so they wanted people with guns to safely store them.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And the court didn't accept that reasonable regulation, but they've accepted many others.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: So I see no conflict between saving people's lives and defending the Second Amendment.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Let me bring Mr. Trump in here.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: The bipartisan Open Debate Coalition got millions of votes on questions to ask here, and this was, in fact, one of the top questions that they got.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: How will you ensure the Second Amendment is protected?

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: You just heard Secretary Clinton's answer.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Does she persuade you that, while you may disagree on regulation, that, in fact, she supports a Second Amendment right to bear arms?

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Well, the D.C. vs. Heller decision was very strongly -- and she was extremely angry about it.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I watched.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I mean, she was very, very angry when upheld.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: And Justice Scalia was so involved.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: And it was a well-crafted decision.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: But Hillary was extremely upset, extremely angry.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: And people that believe in the Second Amendment and believe in it very strongly were very upset with what she had to say.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Well, let me bring in Secretary Clinton.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Were you extremely upset?

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Well, I was upset because, unfortunately, dozens of toddlers injure themselves, even kill people with guns, because, unfortunately, not everyone who has loaded guns in their homes takes appropriate precautions.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: But there's no doubt that I respect the Second Amendment, that I also believe there's an individual right to bear arms.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: That is not in conflict with sensible, commonsense regulation.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And, you know, look, I understand that Donald's been strongly supported by the NRA.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: The gun lobby's on his side.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: They're running millions of dollars of ads against me.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And I regret that, because what I would like to see is for people to come together and say: Of course we're going to protect and defend the Second Amendment.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: But we're going to do it in a way that tries to save some of these 33,000 lives that we lose every year.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Let me bring Mr. Trump back into this, because, in fact, you oppose any limits on assault weapons, any limits on high- capacity magazines.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: You support a national right to carry law.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Why, sir?

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Well, let me just tell you before we go any further.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: In Chicago, which has the toughest gun laws in the United States, probably you could say by far, they have more gun violence than any other city.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: So we have the toughest laws, and you have tremendous gun violence.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I am a very strong supporter of the Second Amendment.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: And I am -- I don't know if Hillary was saying it in a sarcastic manner, but I'm very proud to have the endorsement of the NRA.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: And it's the earliest endorsement they've ever given to anybody who ran for president.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: So I'm very honored by all of that.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We are going to appoint justices -- this is the best way to help the Second Amendment.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We are going to appoint justices that will feel very strongly about the Second Amendment, that will not do damage to the Second Amendment.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Well, let's pick up on another issue which divides you and the justices that whoever ends up winning this election appoints could have a dramatic effect there, and that's the issue of abortion.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Right.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Mr. Trump, you're pro-life.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: But I want to ask you specifically: Do you want the court, including the justices that you will name, to overturn Roe v. Wade, which includes -- in fact, states -- a woman's right to abortion?

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Well, if that would happen, because I am pro-life, and I will be appointing pro-life judges, I would think that that will go back to the individual states.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: But I'm asking you specifically.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Would you like to...

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: If they overturned it, it will go back to the states.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: But what I'm asking you, sir, is, do you want to see the court overturn -- you just said you want to see the court protect the Second Amendment.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Do you want to see the court overturn Roe v. Wade?

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Well, if we put another two or perhaps three justice on, that's really what's going to be -- that will happen.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: And that'll happen automatically, in my opinion, because I am putting pro-life justices on the court.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I will say this: It will go back to the states, and the states will then make a determination.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Secretary Clinton?

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Well, I strongly support Roe v. Wade, which guarantees a constitutional right to a woman to make the most intimate, most difficult, in many cases, decisions about her health care that one can imagine.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And in this case, it's not only about Roe v. Wade.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: It is about what's happening right now in America.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: So many states are putting very stringent regulations on women that block them from exercising that choice to the extent that they are defunding Planned Parenthood, which, of course, provides all kinds of cancer screenings and other benefits for women in our country.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Donald has said he's in favor of defunding Planned Parenthood.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: He even supported shutting the government down to defund Planned Parenthood.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I will defend Planned Parenthood.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I will defend Roe v. Wade, and I will defend women's rights to make their own health care decisions.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Secretary Clintonâ€¦

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And we have come too far to have that turned back now.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: And, indeed, he said women should be punished, that there should be some form of punishment for women who obtain abortions.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: And I could just not be more opposed to that kind of thinking.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: I'm going to give you a chance to respond, but I want to ask you, Secretary Clinton, I want to explore how far you believe the right to abortion goes.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: You have been quoted as saying that the fetus has no constitutional rights.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: You also voted against a ban on late-term, partial-birth abortions.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Why?

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Because Roe v. Wade very clearly sets out that there can be regulations on abortion so long as the life and the health of the mother are taken into account.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And when I voted as a senator, I did not think that that was the case.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: The kinds of cases that fall at the end of pregnancy are often the most heartbreaking, painful decisions for families to make.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I have met with women who toward the end of their pregnancy get the worst news one could get, that their health is in jeopardy if they continue to carry to term or that something terrible has happened or just been discovered about the pregnancy.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I do not think the United States government should be stepping in and making those most personal of decisions.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: So you can regulate if you are doing so with the life and the health of the mother taken into account.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Mr. Trump, your reaction?

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: And particularly on this issue of late-term, partial-birth abortions.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Well, I think it's terrible.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: If you go with what Hillary is saying, in the ninth month, you can take the baby and rip the baby out of the womb of the mother just prior to the birth of the baby.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Now, you can say that that's OK and Hillary can say that that's OK.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: But it's not OK with me, because based on what she's saying, and based on where she's going, and where she's been, you can take the baby and rip the baby out of the womb in the ninth month on the final day.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: And that's not acceptable.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Well, that is not what happens in these cases.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And using that kind of scare rhetoric is just terribly unfortunate.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: You should meet with some of the women that I have met with, women I have known over the course of my life.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: This is one of the worst possible choices that any woman and her family has to make.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And I do not believe the government should be making it.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: You know, I've had the great honor of traveling across the world on behalf of our country.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I've been to countries where governments either forced women to have abortions, like they used to do in China, or forced women to bear children, like they used to do in Romania.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And I can tell you: The government has no business in the decisions that women make with their families in accordance with their faith, with medical advice.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And I will stand up for that right.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: All right.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: But just briefly, I want to move on to another segment...

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: And, honestly, nobody has business doing what I just said, doing that, as late as one or two or three or four days prior to birth.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Nobody has that.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: All right.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Let's move on to the subject of immigration.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: And there is almost no issue that separates the two of you more than the issue of immigration.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Actually, there are a lot of issues that separate the two of you.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Mr. Trump, you want to build a wall.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Secretary Clinton, you have offered no specific plan for how you want to secure our southern border.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Mr. Trump, you are calling for major deportations.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Secretary Clinton, you say that within your first 100 days as president you're going to offer a package that includes a pathway to citizenship.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: The question, really, is, why are you right and your opponent wrong?

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Mr. Trump, you go first in this segment.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: You have two minutes.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Well, first of all, she wants to give amnesty, which is a disaster and very unfair to all of the people that are waiting on line for many, many years.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We need strong borders.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: In the audience tonight, we have four mothers of -- I mean, these are unbelievable people that I've gotten to know over a period of years whose children have been killed, brutally killed by people that came into the country illegally.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: You have thousands of mothers and fathers and relatives all over the country.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: They're coming in illegally.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Drugs are pouring in through the border.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We have no country if we have no border.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Hillary wants to give amnesty.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: She wants to have open borders.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: The border -- as you know, the Border Patrol agents, 16,500-plus ICE last week, endorsed me.

Speaker: TRUMP

Speaker: TRUMP

Speaker: TRUMP

Speaker: TRUMP

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: They want strong borders.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: They feel we have to have strong borders.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I was up in New Hampshire the other day.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: The biggest complaint they have -- it's with all of the problems going on in the world, many of the problems caused by Hillary Clinton and by Barack Obama.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: All of the problems -- the single biggest problem is heroin that pours across our southern border.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: It's just pouring and destroying their youth.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: It's poisoning the blood of their youth and plenty of other people.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We have to have strong borders.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We have to keep the drugs out of our country.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We are -- right now, we're getting the drugs, they're getting the cash.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We need strong borders.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We need absolute -- we cannot give amnesty.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Now, I want to build the wall.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We need the wall.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: And the Border Patrol, ICE, they all want the wall.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We stop the drugs.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We shore up the border.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: One of my first acts will be to get all of the drug lords, all of the bad ones -- we have some bad, bad people in this country that have to go out.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We're going to get them out; we're going to secure the border.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: And once the border is secured, at a later date, we'll make a determination as to the rest.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: But we have some bad hombres here, and we're going to get them out.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Mr. Trump, thank you.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Same question to you, Secretary Clinton.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Basically, why are you right and Mr. Trump is wrong?

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Well, as he was talking, I was thinking about a young girl I met here in Las Vegas, Carla, who is very worried that her parents might be deported, because she was born in this country but they were not.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: They work hard, they do everything they can to give her a good life.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And you're right.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I don't want to rip families apart.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I don't want to be sending parents away from children.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I don't want to see the deportation force that Donald has talked about in action in our country.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We have 11 million undocumented people.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: They have 4 million American citizen children, 15 million people.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: He said as recently as a few weeks ago in Phoenix that every undocumented person would be subject to deportation.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Now, here's what that means.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: It means you would have to have a massive law enforcement presence, where law enforcement officers would be going school to school, home to home, business to business, rounding up people who are undocumented.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And we would then have to put them on trains, on buses to get them out of our country.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I think that is an idea that is not in keeping with who we are as a nation.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I think it's an idea that would rip our country apart.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I have been for border security for years.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I voted for border security in the United States Senate.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And my comprehensive immigration reform plan of course includes border security.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: But I want to put our resources where I think they're most needed: Getting rid of any violent person.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Anybody who should be deported, we should deport them.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: When it comes to the wall that Donald talks about building, he went to Mexico, he had a meeting with the Mexican president.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Didn't even raise it.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: He choked and then got into a Twitter war because the Mexican president said we're not paying for that wall.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: So I think we are both a nation of immigrants and we are a nation of laws and that we can act accordingly.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And that's why I'm introducing comprehensive immigration reform within the first 100 days with the path to citizenship.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Thank you, Secretary Clinton.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: I want to follow up...

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Chris, I think it's...

Speaker: TRUMP

Speaker: TRUMP

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Now, she never gets anything done, so naturally the wall wasn't built.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: But Hillary Clinton wanted the wall.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Well, let me -- wait, wait, sir, let me...

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We are a country of laws.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We either have -- and by the way...

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Now, wait.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: I'd like to hear from...

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Well -- well, but she said one thing.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: I'd like to hear -- I'd like to hear from Secretary Clinton.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I voted for border security, and there are...

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: You know, back in 1987, he took out a $100,000 ad in the New York Times, during the time when President Reagan was president, and basically said exactly what he just said now, that we were the laughingstock of the world.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: He was criticizing President Reagan.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: This is the way Donald thinks about himself, puts himself into, you know, the middle and says, "You know, I alone can fix it," as he said on the convention stage.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: But if you look at the debt, which is the issue you asked about, Chris, I pay for everything I'm proposing.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I do not add a penny to the national debt.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I take that very seriously, because I do think it's one of the issues we've got to come to grips with.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: So when I talk about how we're going to pay for education, how we're going to invest in infrastructure, how we're going to get the cost of prescription drugs down, and a lot of the other issues that people talk to me about all the time, I've made it very clear we are going where the money is.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We are going to ask the wealthy and corporations to pay their fair share.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And there is no evidence whatsoever that that will slow down or diminish our growth.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: In fact, I think just the opposite.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We'll have what economists call middle-out growth.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We've got to get back to rebuilding the middle class, the families of America.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: That's where growth will come from.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: That's why I want to invest in you.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I want to invest in your family.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And I think that's the smartest way to grow the economy, to make the economy fairer.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And we just have a big disagreement about this.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: It may be because of our experiences.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: You know, he started off with his dad as a millionaire...

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Yeah, yeah, we've heard -- we've heard this before, Hillary.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I started off with -- my dad was a small-business man.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We've heard this before.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And I think it -- you know, it's a difference that affects how we see the world and what we want to do with the economy.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Time.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Thank you, Hillary.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Could I just respond?

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Well, no, sir, because we're running out of time...

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Because I did disagree with Ronald Reagan very strongly on trade.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I disagreed with him.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We should have been much tougher on trade even then.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I've been waiting for years.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Nobody does it right.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: OK.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: And frankly, now we're going to do it right.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: All right.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: The one last area I want to get into with you in this debate is the fact that the biggest driver of our debt is entitlements, which is 60 percent of all federal spending.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Now, the Committee for federal -- a Responsible Federal Budget has looked at both of your plans and they say neither of you has a serious plan that is going to solve the fact that Medicare's going to run out of money in the 2020s, Social Security is going to run out of money in the 2030s, and at that time, recipients are going to take huge cuts in their benefits.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: So, in effect, the final question I want to ask you in this regard is -- and let me start with you, Mr. Trump, would President Trump make a deal to save Medicare and Social Security that included both tax increases and benefit cuts, in effect, a grand bargain on entitlements?

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I'm cutting taxes.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We're going to grow the economy.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: It's going to grow at a record rate of growth.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: That's not going to help in the entitlements.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: No, it's going to totally help you.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: And one thing we have to do: Repeal and replace the disaster known as Obamacare.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: It's destroying our country.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: It's destroying our businesses, our small business and our big businesses.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We have to repeal and replace Obamacare.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: You take a look at the kind of numbers that that will cost us in the year '17, it is a disaster.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: If we don't repeal and replace -- now, it's probably going to die of its own weight.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: But Obamacare has to go.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: It's -- the premiums are going up 60 percent, 70 percent, 80 percent.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Next year they're going to go up over 100 percent.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: And I'm really glad that the premiums have started -- at least the people see what's happening, because she wants to keep Obamacare and she wants to make it even worse, and it can't get any worse.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Bad health care at the most expensive price.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We have to repeal and replace Obamacare.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: And, Secretary Clinton, same question, because at this point, Social Security and Medicare are going to run out, the trust funds are going to run out of money.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Will you as president entertain -- will you consider a grand bargain, a deal that includes both tax increases and benefit cuts to try to save both programs?

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Well, Chris, I am on record as saying that we need to put more money into the Social Security Trust Fund.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: That's part of my commitment to raise taxes on the wealthy.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: My Social Security payroll contribution will go up, as will Donald's, assuming he can't figure out how to get out of it.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: But what we want to do is to replenish the Social Security Trust Fund...

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Such a nasty woman.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: by making sure that we have sufficient resources, and that will come from either raising the cap and/or finding other ways to get more money into it.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I will not cut benefits.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I want to enhance benefits for low-income workers and for women who have been disadvantaged by the current Social Security system.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: But what Donald is proposing with these massive tax cuts will result in a $20 trillion additional national debt.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: That will have dire consequences for Social Security and Medicare.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And I'll say something about the Affordable Care Act, which he wants to repeal.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: The Affordable Care Act extended the solvency of the Medicare Trust Fund.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: So if repeals it, our Medicare problem gets worse.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: What we need to do is go after...

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Your husband disagrees with you.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: the long-term health care drivers.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We've got to get costs down, increase value, emphasize wellness.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I have a plan for doing that.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And I think that we will be able to get entitlement spending under control by with more resources and harder decisions.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: This is -- this is the final time, probably to both of your delight, that you're going to be on a stage together in this campaign.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: I would like to end it on a positive note.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: You had not agreed to closing statements, but it seems to me in a funny way that might make it more interesting because you haven't prepared closing statements.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: So I'd like you each to take -- and we're going to put a clock up, a minute, as the final question in the final debate, to tell the American people why they should elect you to be the next president.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: This is another new mini-segment.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Secretary Clinton, it's your turn to go first.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: Well, I would like to say to everyone watching tonight that I'm reaching out to all Americans -- Democrats, Republicans, and independents -- because we need everybody to help make our country what it should be, to grow the economy, to make it fairer, to make it work for everyone.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: We need your talents, your skills, your commitments, your energy, your ambition.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: You know, I've been privileged to see the presidency up close.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: And I know the awesome responsibility of protecting our country and the incredible opportunity of working to try to make life better for all of you.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I have made the cause of children and families really my life's work.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: That's what my mission will be in the presidency.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I will stand up for families against powerful interests, against corporations.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I will do everything that I can to make sure that you have good jobs, with rising incomes, that your kids have good educations from preschool through college.

Speaker: CLINTON
Text: I hope you will give me a chance to serve as your president.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Secretary Clinton, thank you.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Mr. Trump?

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: She's raising the money from the people she wants to control.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Doesn't work that way.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: But when I started this campaign, I started it very strongly.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: It's called "Make America Great Again."

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We're going to make America great.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We have a depleted military.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: It has to be helped, has to be fixed.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We have the greatest people on Earth in our military.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We don't take care of our veterans.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We take care of illegal immigrants, people that come into the country illegally, better than we take care of our vets.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: That can't happen.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Our policemen and women are disrespected.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We need law and order, but we need justice, too.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: Our inner cities are a disaster.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: You get shot walking to the store.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: They have no education.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: They have no jobs.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: I will do more for African-Americans and Latinos than she can ever do in 10 lifetimes.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: All she's done is talk to the African-Americans and to the Latinos, but they get the vote, and then they come back, they say, we'll see you in four years.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We are going to make America strong again, and we are going to make America great again, and it has to start now.

Speaker: TRUMP
Text: We cannot take four more years of Barack Obama, and that's what you get when you get her.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Thank you both.

Text: (APPLAUSE)

Text: Secretary Clinton -- hold on just a moment, folks.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Secretary Clinton, Mr. Trump, I want to thank you both for participating in all three of these debates.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: That brings to an end this year's debates sponsored by the Commission on Presidential Debates.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: We want to thank the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, and its students for having us.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Now the decision is up to you.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: While millions have already voted, Election Day, November 8th, is just 20 days away.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: One thing everyone here can agree on: We hope you will go vote.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: It is one of the honors and obligations of living in this great country.

Speaker: WALLACE
Text: Thank you, and good night.
